docs.snippet: Running on up to 20 percent biodiesel and topped with solar panels and a wind turbine, the redesigned Planters promotional vehicle makes its debut at the Global Green Oscars preparty this week....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Nutmobile, the peanut-shaped traveling ambassador for the Planters brand, is going green. Its newest iteration runs on biodiesel and has a wind turbine, solar panels, LED interior lighting, recycled parts and wood floors reclaimed from a 19th century Pennsylvania barn. It will make its public debut at the Global Green Oscars preparty in Los Angeles on Wednesday.
docs.abstract: Running on up to 20 percent biodiesel and topped with solar panels and a wind turbine, the redesigned Planters promotional vehicle makes its debut at the Global Green Oscars preparty this week.

headline.main: A Green Makeover for Planters Nutmobile

docs.snippet: Susanne Bier, the director of "In a Better World," talks about tackling aggression in film, exploring the divide between the West and the Third World and how much an Oscar nomination means to countries like Denmark....
docs.lead_paragraph: Susanne Bier's "In a Better World" goes into Sunday's Academy Awards as the favorite to capture the Oscar for best foreign-language film, if only because it won the Golden Globe in that category last month. The film, which is mainly in Danish, is a thoughtful and complex movie, set in a quiet village in Denmark and in a refugee camp in an African country riven by civil war. A compassionate but flawed Danish doctor serves, in Ms. Bier's words, as "the character who bridges those two worlds."
docs.abstract: Susanne Bier, the director of "In a Better World," talks about tackling aggression in film, exploring the divide between the West and the Third World and how much an Oscar nomination means to countries like Denmark.

headline.main: Searching for a Place 'In a Better World'

docs.snippet: The hiker who self-amputated his arm has found all the hoopla over "127 Hours" a complicated kind of celebration....
docs.lead_paragraph: With all the attention being paid to James "culturally omnipresent" Franco -- being everywhere all the time kind of makes you a go-to target, especially for people looking for go-to targets -- it's almost easy to forget that Mr. Franco is getting Oscar attention not just for manic multitasking but for playing a real person: the hiker Aron Ralston, whose true story inspired "127 Hours."
docs.abstract: The hiker who self-amputated his arm has found all the hoopla over "127 Hours" a complicated kind of celebration.

headline.main: The Surreal Life of Aron Ralston

docs.snippet: Diane Von Furstenberg backs away from her criticism of Michelle Obama....
docs.lead_paragraph: Is Diane Von Furstenberg having second thoughts about joining the chorus of designers - most notably Oscar de la Renta - who criticized Michelle Obama for wearing an Alexander McQueen dress to a state dinner last month, and not one by an American designer?
docs.abstract: Diane Von Furstenberg backs away from her criticism of Michelle Obama.

docs.snippet: Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune, makes her pitch for a category honoring opening and closing credits and offers up her nominees (and winner)....
docs.lead_paragraph: Are there enough categories in the Academy Awards race? Not according to Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune. She proposes an Oscar for the opening and closing credits and offers her own nominees for the most creative, or effective, of this movie season. Typography is important but not always paramount. Her standard is one set by Saul Bass, who worked on Hitchcock, Kubrick and Scorsese films among many others: Do the credits set the mood for the movie to come? As he said in a 1966 interview with Film Quarterly, "I saw the title as a way of conditioning the audience, so that when the film actually began, viewers would have an emotional resonance with it."
docs.abstract: Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune, makes her pitch for a category honoring opening and closing credits and offers up her nominees (and winner).

headline.main: If There Were an Oscar for Title Sequences

docs.snippet: The American Cinema Editors' choice, a good predictor for the best picture Oscar, has scrambled the race as it heads into the home stretch....
docs.lead_paragraph: With less than a week to go, the pace of tea-leaf-reading - and stirring - is approaching Daytona levels. On Saturday the American Cinema Editors guild, considered a good harbinger of the best picture Oscar, announced its winners (known as the Eddies), and it was enough to cause - if we're going to keep going with this metaphor - a tempest in a teapot. The big prize went to Angus Wall and Kirk Baxter for "The Social Network" over "The King's Speech" (and over "Black Swan," "The Fighter" and "Inception"). In the comedy/musical category, "Alice in Wonderland" bested "The Kids Are All Right" and several other non-Oscar contenders, and "Exit Through the Gift Shop" won for documentary - an illustration of how well-liked it is as a film. Meanwhile pundits pounced on a victory for anything other than the projected favorite, "The King's Speech."
docs.abstract: The American Cinema Editors' choice, a good predictor for the best picture Oscar, has scrambled the race as it heads into the home stretch.

headline.main: Editors Pick 'Social Network,' Adding Some Oscar Intrigue
